bib_record.title: Measurements of neutron capture cross-section for tantalum at the neutron filtered beams

free_txt: All results presented
first result at 59 keV
first result at 2 keV
Data with revised uncertainties
Reactor WWR-M
Correction on the resonance self-shielding of neutrons
in the tantalic samples was done. The real values of
cross-sections were received by extrapolation the
observed cross sections to zero thickness of the
samples.
To estimate a share of cross-section from the impure
lines, a numerical simulation was performed.
Corrections for backward scattering of neutrons by the
output collimator were computed with program package
MCNP-4C for real irradiation conditions.
Detector type - DGDK-45A; energy resolution -
3.4 keV at 1332 keV gamma-line; lead shield with 15 cm
thickness.
Spectrometer with two Ge(Li) detectors
DGDK-32B was placed at the horizontal channel and used
to determine the incident neutron flux.
The spectrometer was calibrated on energy and
efficiency using the sources 133Ba and 152Eu from the
SOSGI-M standard set. The value of the absolute
efficiency of registration for gamma-line 478 keV from
reaction 10B(n,alpha+gamma) was (3.08+-0.17)*10-5.
Exposing the tantalic targets, simultaneously
the monitoring of the neutron flux has been done by the
neutron spectrometer with 3He-counter. The measurements
of the neutron beam have been done every 1000 s after
each 2600 s of the total exposition.
Reactor WWR-M
Neutron filters installed in horizontal channel
of the reactor.
Activation of tantalic samples was done
during 84 hours for 2 keV and 62 + 84 hours for 59 keV,
then the targets were removed to the clean zone for the
further measurements.
The neutron flux was
defined by area of the full absorption peak of gamma
rays with 478 keV energy (the excited state of 7Li).
Cross sections of the 10B(n,alpha+gamma)7Li* reaction
were calculated as mean values of the averaged on a
filtered neutron beam shape of the point-wise cross
sections, taken from CENDL-2, ENDF/B-VI, JENDL-3.3 and
The tantalic targets were made
of natural tantalum foil and the targets had the
28.0 mm diameter.
The boron target used to define the
neutron flux value, was made of the boric powder,
enriched by 10B. This target is placed inside the
container  with 28 mm diameter. The thickness of the
boron target was 1 mm, weight = 0.6732 g.
Absolute uncertainty of cross section-
it includes the uncertainties of-
Error in extrapolated cross-section - it
includes the uncertainties of-
error in determination of sample activities 1.7-4.4%
statistical error in peak area 1.0-5.0%
error in gamma-line efficiency 4.2%
Error in determination of Ta sample mass 0.011%
Error in determination of neutron flux - it
includes the uncertainties of-
error in determination of B sample mass 0.024%
error in the B gamma-line efficiency 2.04%
error in quantum yield gamma-lines 0.05-0.48
error in cross section of the 10-B(n,alpha+gamma)7-Li
reaction 0.50%
Error due to the impure lines in filtered beam
Error due to backward scattering of neutrons by
the output collimator 0.3%
Filter 2 keV.  Average energy of filtered neutron
(1.795 (+0.645,-0.724))keV (95% response function),
the filter components (g/cm2):
Purity of beam about 95.73%, main parasitic lines:
Neutron flux was 8.9e+06 n/cm2/s. Time of irradiation
A pile of four 0.2 mm thickness tantalic targets was
used.
Private communication with Gritzay (2011)
Neutron spectrum after filter 2 keV

it includes the uncertainties of-

includes the uncertainties of-
error in determination of sample activities 1.3-4.4%
statistical error in peak area 1.2-21.1%
error in gamma-line efficiency 4.2%
error in quantum yield gamma-lines 0.05-0.48
Error in determination of Ta sample mass 0.057%
Error in determination of neutron flux - it
includes the uncertainties of-
error in determination of B sample mass 0.024%
error in the B gamma-line efficiency 2.04%
error in cross section of the 10-B(n,alpha+gamma)7-Li
reaction 1.29%
Error due to the impure lines in filtered beam
Error due to backward scattering of neutrons by
the output collimator 3.7%
Filter 59 keV.  Average energy of filtered neutron
the filter components (g/cm2): 58Ni - 84.55, S - 157.7,
V - 17.4, Pb - 2.5, Al - 5.4, 10B - 0.2. The purity of
beam was about 97.0%, main parasitic lines:
Neutron flux was 2.62e+06 n/cm2/s. Total time of
irradiation was 527040 s.
A pile of eight 0.1 mm thickness tantalic targets was
used.
Private communication with Gritzay (2011)
